bestBHT.bht: When sending out the disciples, Jesus instructed them to go out with only the bare essentials, emphasizing the simplicity and dependence on God. The mention of two in the command probably indicates that they were not to indulge in luxury or excessive preparation, but rather rely on the hospitality of others. Jesus wanted them to be unencumbered by worldly concerns, have their minds set solely on their mission, and be reminded of God's care and provision.

Philip Schaff: With sandals, i.e., such as they had on at the time, without waiting for shoes especially adapted for the journey.
The construction changes into a direct command in the last clause, as if the memory of one present had supplied it.
Archibald T. Robertson: The mention of 'two' here in all three Gospels probably helps us to understand that the same thing applies to shoes and staff.
Two was a sign of comparative wealth.
In general, these directions are against luxury in equipment, and also against their providing themselves with what they could procure from the hospitality of others.
John Gill: They were forbid change of raiment; the reasons for it.
A minister of the Gospel ought not to be a worldly minded man.
He ought to have his mind free from all solicitude and anxious concern.
John Wesley: Be shod with sandals — As you usually are.
Our Lord intended by this mission to initiate them into their apostolic work.

And it was doubtless an encouragement to them all their life after, to recollect the care which God took of them, when they had left all they had, and went out quite unfurnished for such an expedition.

bhtAttempts.bht: When sending out the disciples, Jesus instructed them to go out with only the bare essentials, emphasizing the simplicity and dependence on God that were necessary for their mission. The mention of two in the command to not take money or extra clothes probably indicates that they were not to indulge in luxury or excessive preparation. In fact, they were to rely on the hospitality of others, rather than providing for themselves. This directive was not only a practical instruction, but also a reminder for the disciples to maintain a mindset of faith and trust in God throughout their ministry. Jesus wanted them to be unencumbered by worldly concerns and to have their minds set solely on their mission. The use of sandals was also specified, highlighting the customary footwear for travel rather than waiting for more comfortable or specialized shoes. This was a symbolic way of preparing the disciples for their apostolic work and reminding them of God's care and provision, even when they had left everything behind.

The command to rely on the hospitality of others instead of providing for themselves highlighted the importance of faith and trust in God. This directive not only prepared the disciples practically for their mission, but also served as a reminder to keep their minds free from worldly concerns and fully focused on their purpose.
